description: The Conversion rule transforms a biconditional into its equivalence form. "P if and only if Q" means either both are true OR both are false: (P ∧ Q) ∨ (¬P ∧ ¬Q). This is a single-operation rule that generates BOTH disjuncts at once.

problems.solution: Apply Conversion to expand the biconditional into its equivalence form: both true or both false.
Apply Conversion to show R and S have the same truth value.
Apply Conversion where the left side is a disjunction.
Apply Conversion where the right side is a conjunction.
Apply Conversion to a biconditional between two implications.
Apply Conversion to get (P ∧ Q) ∨ (¬P ∧ ¬Q), then extract the first disjunct with Simplification.
Apply Conversion to the biconditional, showing that since both P and Q are true, the equivalence form holds.
Apply Conversion, use Disjunctive Syllogism with the negated conjunction to derive ¬R.
Apply Conversion to both biconditionals, use logical reasoning to derive that P and R must also have the same truth value.
